item.title: The Indie Game Awards 2025 Set for December, Full Nominee List Revealed
item.content:encoded:
The nominees for The Indie Game Awards 2025 have been revealed, so if you're tired of all the talk surrounding this year's main Game Awards ceremony, step right this way.

As revealed over on the official Indie Game Awards website, this year's ceremony will be taking place on December 18th at 3:30pm Pacific (that's around 6:30pm Eastern and about 11:30pm GMT). Games will compete across eighteen categories, including overall Game of the Year, as well as more specific fields like Best Debut and Music.

There will also be three special categories - Indie Vanguard, the Mohammad Fahmi Storyteller Award, and Industry Impact - which recognize specific achievements within the industry.

As you can imagine, this year's big indie hits are well-represented in the Indie Game Awards, with major successes like Hollow Knight: Silksong and Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 nominated across multiple categories.

Other, smaller indie titles, like shop sim Discounty, Soulslike Fly Knight, and Zelda-style adventure Pipistrello and the Cursed Yoyo, have also been given nods, as have innovative efforts like Blue Prince and Ruffy and the Riverside.

Solo-developed games like Antonblast, Lushfoil Photography Sim, and Vile: Exhumed (complete with all of its Steam-related controversy) have also been acknowledged for their developers' efforts, and various regions and countries around the world, including Latin America, Southeast Asia, and South Africa, have their own categories.

You can check out a trailer announcing all of the nominees, as well as many of the presenters who will be present to present the awards, as it were, right here.

The community will also be given a chance to submit games they think have excelled in certain areas as part of the Indie Game Awards' Community Picks, so if you'd like to nominate something you feel has been unfairly overlooked, you can do so right here.

2025's Indie Game Awards will air in various places, including organizer Six One Indie's YouTube channel, on December 18th at 3:30pm Pacific. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Over 200 Rockstar Employees Demand Reinstatement of Fired Staffers
item.content:encoded:
More than 200 Rockstar employees have signed a letter demanding that a number of colleagues recently fired for "misconduct" be reinstated, alleging union-busting.

As spotted by Eurogamer, the letter requests the reinstatement of over 30 Rockstar employees who were let go from the company recently. All of the employees were involved in union activity, leading Independent Workers' Union of Great Britain (IWGB) organizer Fred Carter to call the dismissals an "act of union-busting unprecedented in the games industry".

An anonymous employee, who was one of those recently fired, told Eurogamer that the firings constitute "a blatant, unapologetic act of vicious union busting", and that it's "heartwarming" to see colleagues supporting them and "holding management to account".

Rockstar and parent company Take-Two's side of things is that the employees were fired for "misconduct"; the two studios suggest that the employees in question were involved in leaking key information about the recently-delayed Grand Theft Auto 6, a claim that the IWGB disputes enough to hit Rockstar with a legal complaint.

The news comes after the aforementioned delay to GTA 6, which is the second time the game has been pushed back; it was originally slated for a May release, but was delayed in order to give Rockstar more time to work on it.

When GTA 6 does eventually launch, it's likely to break sales records across the industry; Take-Two says the game will constitute an "unrivalled blockbuster entertainment experience", and some investors are predicting revenues upwards of $7 billion within the first two months of release.

Whether that figure is accurate or not, it's likely that GTA 6 will surpass its predecessor in sales and revenue terms, and since GTA 5 earned $800 million in its first day, GTA 6 is going to be massive.

We'll have to wait and see what comes of these Rockstar employees' demands. Stay tuned for more.
